moves.1. d4 b6 2. e4 Bb7 3. Bd3 h6: This opening is a very unusal one by Black. A Queen's pawn game (A40) English defence, but h6 is a new move.
moves.4. Nf3 Nf6 5. d5 e6 6. c4 exd5 7. exd5 Q: ? This move forces Queen exchange and the center is gone for Black.
After the opening, Black lost a rook, and White has two powerful bishops on the a1-h8 and b1-h7 diagonal line.
This move is decisive for the game. Black needs the knight for the rook Re8. Better is  Nc7. White can break into the d and e file now more quickly.
moves.22. Rad1 Ba6: ?? The second rook is captured. Be7 was urgently needed.
moves.23. Bd7 Rc8 24. Bxc8 Bxc8 25. Rhe1: The rook threatens for a rook fork at the bishops. But Bf8 can not move.
moves.26. Re8 Bh6 27. Nb5 Kb7 28. Nxd6+: Bc8 is lost by a knight fork.
moves.28... Ka6 29. Rxc8 g4+ 30. hxg4:
An analysis by Toga gave check mate in 7 or 8 moves.
[30. ..Ka5? 31. Rc7 Ka6 32. Rc3 Nc2 33. Rd4 Nxd4  34. Bxd4 hxg4  35. Kxg4 Ka5 36. Ra3  Kb4 37. Rb3  Ka4 38. Bc3 b5 39. Ra3#]
[30. .. hxg4? 31. Kxg4 Ka5 32 Rd4 Bf8 33. Rxf8 Nc2 34. Rc4 Nd4 35. Ra8 Nc6 36. Rxa7 Nxa7 37. Bc3  Ka6 38. Ra4#]
[30. .. Bg7? 31. Bxg7 hxg4 32. Kxg4 Ka5 33. Bc3 b5 34. Rc6 Ka4 35. Nb7 a6 36. Nc5  Ka5 37. Rxa6#]
[30. .. Bf8? 31. Rxf8 Ka5 32. Bc3 b5 33. gxh5 Ka6 34. Bxb4 Kb6 35. Rb8  Ka6 36. Rc8 Kb6 37. Rc6#]
Black is check mate if the bishop is taken or not. 34. .. Kxb4 35. Rd4  Ka5 26. Nb7  Kb5 37. a4#
